posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: Our team has consistently utilized a daisy-chained CAN bus system, which unfortunately carries the risk of a single failure affecting the entire robot's functionality. We've been exploring improvements to our CAN setup and currently plan to employ two CANivores to separately manage the drivetrain and superstructure, ensuring the drivetrain remains operational and enabling defensive measures in case of a failure. Considering further redundancy, we considered implementing a Star topology, which involves maintaining the drivetrain in a daisy-chained configuration while introducing a hub on the superstructure bus to establish Star topology. However, given the potential complexities and risks associated with correctly setting up Star topology, we sought advice from our team on its feasibility, best practices, alternative topologies, and drawbacks.

posts.name: Drew Williams
posts.cooked:
Using a carnival with daisy chaining can cause reliability issues with your CAN bus. To ensure a robust setup, follow these guidelines:

1. **Pre-Twisted Wire**: Use pre-twisted CAN wire to minimize signal degradation.
2. **Proper Connections**: Opt for Molex SL connectors or solder with excellent technique to maintain signal integrity.
3. **Protection**: Jacketed wires are ideal where components might be exposed to environmental factors.
4. **Avoid Overstubs**: Keep any stubs under 12 inches to prevent signal loss.
5. **Strain Relief**: Incorporate strain reliefs to distribute electrical stress evenly.
6. **Regular Checks**: Conduct system checks before each competition to catch and resolve issues early.

For more details, refer to discussions on CAN connection preferences and troubleshooting tips for a more informed setup.

link_counts.title: What Are the Best Practices for a Reliable CAN Bus Setup?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
The text has been converted to a single, continuous paragraph while removing unnecessary elements such as HTML tags, abbreviations, and additional formatting:

The star bus topology has been reliable for our low-speed network for nearly a decade, especially after improving connection methods. With the shift toward CTRE ecosystem integration, we've utilized CAN FD primarily for our robots. However, due to its dependency on CTRE control functionality, CAN FD becomes resource-intensive. While it worked with fewer than 10 devices once, it was prone to instability. We predominantly use CANivore and CAN FD in a daisy chain configuration for drivetrain components since these are in critical areas. Everything else runs on RIO/CAN 2.0 via custom hubs developed over the years. Over the past two years, we've experienced zero CAN issues during competitions, with only a brief problem in 2023 involving a stubborn CANCoder.

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: That's what I thought. I was a bit confused because I had heard about star topology on a CANivore before. So, if we decide not to use a CANivore for the superstructure bus, we could still opt for a star topology instead. Otherwise, we might go with daisy chaining. Thanks for the threads; I'll check them out later.

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: This seems like what I was thinking. I found a hub on Playing With Fusion that’s similar to your custom one. Are all the devices you run on the Star bus strictly non-CTRE devices like NEOs? We run a full CTRE ecosystem with Kraken modules, so I doubt this would work for us.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
No, this past year we ran all Cross The Road Electronics as well but still used this configuration. Star offers a lot of redundancy since a single failure won’t take down the whole network generally especially when moving parts are involved. The drivetrain is also the biggest drain on CAN network utilization so once you separate that out you can pretty much run everything else on CAN 2.0 with no issues.

In general my preference would be to run everything on Star if it weren’t for the limited bandwidth of the 2.0 network. Running both is more of a compromise solution than anything but it’s good enough if you’re smart about it. A team without a high CAN bus utilization on 2.0 could probably use Star for the whole robot with no issues we are just not one of those teams.

The Playing with Fusion boards are pretty similar to ours so you’d probably be fine going that way. Swyft also has an interesting solution for Daisy Chain CAN and power though I don’t know how much I trust RJ45 connectors.

link_counts.title: SWYFT CANnect Wiring System – SWYFT Robotics

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: Our programming team believes managing more than 4 Kraken nodes on the 2.0 network will be challenging, but I plan to discuss this matter in greater depth. Daisy chaining our swerve drive separately seems manageable. The Swyft solution is intriguing, yet I haven't made up my mind yet.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
We had approximately 7 Kraken systems along with 3-4 sensors operating on our 2.0 network this year without encountering any utilization issues. The primary reason why separating the drive motors on a swerve platform from the 2.0 network leads to significant performance improvements lies in the communication mechanism established by CTRE (Cross The Road Electronics). This environment facilitates effective interaction between swerve motors and sensors. However, when individual motors manage their own PID loops and functions independently, the overall network load remains manageable compared to the full network integration.

If you're experiencing challenges running more than four standalone Kraken systems on your 2.0 network, it may be worthwhile to reach out to CTRE’s support team. They are typically very helpful and could provide further insight into whether you're implementing the system correctly.

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked:
This is the wiring topology of a typical CANbus. A CTRE-style daisy chain is used, with each node connected via connectors on the wire segments, potentially causing breakpoints along the bus. These blue dots represent device connections in the daisy chain.  

Here is an image of the setup.  

Another example of this configuration is shown here.  

The risk of multiple termination points on the CANbus makes it less desirable, and my preferred solution is to use 22AWG wire taps.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: STAR Topology has had an excellent year with our setup. We utilized a combined shielded high-low signal cable, ensuring reliability. Each swerve module and subsystem received its own dedicated CAN network setup, resulting in zero failures throughout the season—a stark contrast to previous matches where we didn't upgrade as seriously. Highly recommended. Our device plugs connect via green/yellow cables using a combination of crimp and heat-shrink connectors.

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: The information here is great and I've been learning a lot so thanks to everyone. One question I have is about stub length. I know that they're supposed to stay under 12 but this seems impossible to me since I feel like motors and other devices are inevitably going to be further than 12 from the hub. How do you get around this?

posts.name: BrianAtlanta
posts.cooked: You run your CAN wire close to the device. The curved line represents your CAN connection, and the box on the line indicates your connector of choice for tapping into the CAN system.

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: So would this be if you ran a wire from the Rio close to motors and other devices and then used wiretaps instead of a hub to make branches?

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked: Keep in mind that more options than just daisy chain and star topology exist. Your bus' trunk (consisting of the main CAN_H & CAN_L wires) can be routed in a logical path to keep stubs under 12 inches. Use wire taps to split these stubs away from the trunk.

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked: This is probably crazy, expensive, and certainly not scientifically based—while we used a daisy chain layout last year, we ended up using two CANivores to separate segments of our robot, which might have introduced additional potential failure points via USB connections to the RoboRIO. However, adopting a more reliable approach, we exclusively use Kraken and CANcoders, constructing our own CAN segments between devices—cutting costs and minimizing solder connections (except on CANcoders and terminating resistors). Additionally, we favor jacketed wire for areas prone to being cut, though we all prefer to avoid cutting through the jacket to prevent nicks to the green/yellow wires.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH.

The text is: 

The CTRE's can implementation doesn’t require daisy chain although it’s strongly recommended. It is far more sensitive to star “abuse” than the rio’s native and slower can.

We used the canivore, and used a hybrid topology. This is what it looked like:

The small squares are what I’ll call a “hub”. It’s where we broke out the star from the trunk line.

We did have problems with the can bus on initial setup. We kept stub lengths as short as possible. What we found, however, was that when we had two stubs close together, say the intake and a swerve module, and the linear distance if you measured back to the canivore along the wires overlapped, we would have problems. This wasn’t surprising. As a result, when we had an issue like that, we would extend the wires between the hubs.

This is a picture of what I mean:

On the right in the above diagram, the Intake “star” is long enough that it’s length back to the canivore overlaps with a device on the swerve “star”. The fix to this was to extend the cable between the intake and swerve so the devices are a significantly different 'wire' distance from the canivore as those on another star.

Following that worked. However…

Take this all with a giant grain of salt. It took us a couple tries to get the lengths correct as we worked through the bus. And I was worried about the 'what if it fails' all season. At one point, we made a minor change to one of the stars during practice and it took the bus down until we lengthened another cable. It can be tricky, and you can spend a lot of time diagnosing a problem that you really shouldn’t be wasting time on.

Daisy chaining is the simple, reliable answer to the question “how should I run my can bus wiring?” Just ask yourself “Do I want to be programming the robot, or troubleshooting my can bus?”

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: The root cause of many CAN problems being reported is due to bad or unreliable connections rather than the topology used. Either topology, if poorly implemented, will perform poorly. By improving procedures for electrical connections, you can enhance the reliability of your control system and robot. Ensure your team performs a tug-test on each wire immediately after making the connection. Ensure connectors cannot come apart and use a small zip-tie for the black PWM connectors supplied with SparkMax. Strain-relieved wires on both sides of connectors prevent tension during movement. Avoid tension on wires, especially at connection points. Include a service loop at each connector to allow movement without transferring force and enable easier servicing. These practices are commonly used in industry.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version:

Yes this is my test setup on bench. I am using a star network with WAGO connector for ease of connection. Don’t ever try this on a real robot. It’s completely not up to standard but works completely fine. All my wires are less than two inches.

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked:
Time for the first of hopefully a few writeups on successful practices we implemented this year that we will do before the season starts. 

Wiring Writeup  
We have had wiring issues for a long time, but this year we had one of our alumni come back to become a mentor. He does motorsports electronics, and helped us improve our wiring for this season. Information in this post comes from him via [this writeup](https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/what-wire-connectors-do-you-use/475352/63) from @Footie. In addition, thanks to @Baby_Carrot and @Big_Ideas for additional info and clarification…

My team has been using trunk-and-branch can topology for the past two years (see above writeup) and it has worked very well for us.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: The root cause of many CAN problems is often bad connections, not the topology. While a star topology with a high-speed CAN FD bus may introduce issues like ringing or reflections, especially with poor wiring. Daisy chaining offers a simpler, more reliable solution for wiring robots. If I'm programming or fixing the bus, a daisy chain is better. But if I'm just setting it up, the native CAN2.0 on the ROBO RIO might work fine.
